column18: not the same as Ramon Llull - this is the pseudonym of an alchemical school
column47: Sacri Doctoris Raymundi Lulli de secretis naturae sive the quinta essentia Libellus
column76: There is a prior, 1514 edition of De secretis naturae which was included in the Consiliorum... published in Venice. There is another 1518 edition in Venice.

column47: Ars transmutationis metallicae cum Leonis X Ponti. Max. et Conci. Capi. Decemvirum Venetormv edicto.
column76: This book was first published in 1518 with an imprimatur of Pope Leo X signed by Pietro Bembo (Bembus). It is very rare and the only online copy is on Google Books, originating from the British Library.

column47: Commentarium transmutationis metallicae
column76: This 1519 book is catalogued wrongly by many libraries, including BSB/MDZ, as Ars transmutationis metallicae. It includes this Ars but adds the Commentarium as well.

column18: This is a compendium of various notes and letters written by Sebastian Montuus, Manardus, Symphorien Champier, Dionysius Coronaeus, Bernard Unger
column36: Monteux belonged to the circle of Symphorien Champier
column47: Annotatiunculae Sebastiani Montui artium, ac Medicinae doctoris in errata recentiorum medicorum per Leonardum Fuchsium collecta. Apologetica epistola pro defensione Arabum composita a domino Bernardo Unger Germano composita. Epistola responsiva pro Graecorum defensione in Arabum errata a Symphoriano Campegio composita
column76: This work is a compendium of writings belonging, apparently, to the circle of Symphorien Champier. Monteux was against the use of images in prints, according to Kusukawa 1997, and was responded to by Leonard Fuchs himself. There is a letter on the transmutation of metals by Champier himself.

column18: Philopistius Agricola is said to have been the pseudonym of Daniel Agricola in the preface.
column43: Mistakingly stated as 1531 in Hirsch 1950 (due to false identification of Agricola with Georgius)
column47: Galerazeya : Siue Revelator Secretorvm I. De Lapide Philosophorum, II. De Arabico Elyzir, III. De Auro Potabili & Pomis Paradisi
column61:
The publisher is given as Petrus Metternich, prope 
Augustinianos
column76: This work has been mistakingly ascribed to Georgius Agricola by various scholars. Ferguson 1906 sets them straight, but Hirsch still makes the same mistake. There is a Jesuit emblem to the frontispiece. Ferguson says this is not a treatise on alchemy at all but an instrument of Roman Catholic conversion. It's very difficult to find a clean copy online.
